Exam Review

State: An example [2/17]

Remember the awful finite state machine from Homework 3?

file:Control.java [source]

Here is a version refactored to the state pattern:

file:Control.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.ui.main;
00002: 
00003: import state.ui.UI;
00004: import state.ui.UIMenu;
00005: import state.ui.UIMenuAction;
00006: import state.ui.UIMenuBuilder;
00007: import state.ui.UIForm;
00008: import state.ui.UIFormTest;
00009: import state.ui.UIFormBuilder;
00010: 
00011: class Control {
00012:   final State EXITED; 
00013:   final State EXIT; 
00014:   private State _state;
00015:   private UI _ui;
00016:   Control(UI ui) {
00017:     EXITED = new ExitedState();
00018:     EXIT = new ExitState(this,ui);
00019:     _ui = ui;
00020:     _state = EXIT;
00021:   }
00022:   
00023:   void run() {
00024:     while (_state != EXITED) {
00025:       _state = _state.run();
00026:     } 
00027:   }
00028: }
00029: 
00030: interface State {
00031:   public State run();
00032: }
00033: 
00034: final class ExitedState implements State {
00035:   public State run() {
00036:     return this;
00037:   }
00038: }
00039: 
00040: final class ExitState implements State {
00041:   Control _control;
00042:   UI _ui;
00043:   UIMenu _m;
00044:   ExitState(Control control, UI ui) {
00045:     _control = control;
00046:     _ui = ui;
00047: 
00048:     UIMenuBuilder m;
00049:     m = new UIMenuBuilder();
00050:     
00051:     m.add("Default", new UIMenuAction() { public Object run() {return this;} });
00052:     m.add("Yes",
00053:       new UIMenuAction() {
00054:         public Object run() {
00055:           return _control.EXITED;
00056:         }
00057:       });
00058:     m.add("No",
00059:       new UIMenuAction() {
00060:         public Object run() {
00061:           return _control.EXIT;
00062:         }
00063:       });
00064:     _m = m.toUIMenu("Are you sure you want to exit?");
00065:   }
00066:   public State run() {
00067:     return (State) _ui.processMenu(_m);
00068:   }
00069: }

Full code: dir:state/ui [source]

State: General form [3/17]

State: Initial code [4/17]

Discuss intrinsic/extrinsic state and field/parameter refactorings.

file:I.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.one;
00002: 
00003: interface I {
00004:   public int f();
00005:   public int g();
00006:   public void changeDirection();
00007: }
00008: 
00009: class C implements I {
00010:   private boolean _state;
00011:   private int _i;
00012:   private int _j;
00013:   public int f() {
00014:     if (_state)
00015:       _i += 26;
00016:     else
00017:       _i -= 32;
00018:     return _i;
00019:   }
00020:   public int g() {
00021:     if (_state)
00022:       _j += 42;
00023:     else
00024:       _j -= 27;
00025:     return _j;
00026:   }
00027:   public void changeDirection() {
00028:     _state = !_state;
00029:   }
00030: }

State: Refactored to state using inner class [5/17]

file:I.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.five;
00002: 
00003: interface I {
00004:   public int f();
00005:   public int g();
00006:   public void changeDirection();
00007: }
00008: 
00009: class C implements I {
00010:   private State _state = new StateMinus();
00011:   private int _i;
00012:   private int _j;
00013:   public int f() {
00014:     return _state.f();
00015:   }
00016:   public int g() {
00017:     return _state.g();
00018:   }
00019:   public void changeDirection() {
00020:     _state = _state.next();
00021:   }
00022: 
00023:   interface State {
00024:     public int f();
00025:     public int g();
00026:     public State next();
00027:   }
00028:   class StateMinus implements State {
00029:     public int f() {
00030:       _i -= 32;
00031:       return _i;
00032:   }
00033:     public int g() {
00034:       _j -= 27;
00035:       return _j;
00036:     }
00037:     public State next() {
00038:       return new StatePlus();
00039:     }
00040:   }
00041:   class StatePlus implements State {
00042:     public int f() {
00043:       _i += 26;
00044:       return _i;
00045:     }
00046:     public int g() {
00047:       _j += 42;
00048:       return _j;
00049:     }
00050:     public State next() {
00051:       return new StateMinus();
00052:     }
00053:   }
00054: }
00055:

State: Refactored to state using explicit field [6/17]

file:I.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.four;
00002: 
00003: interface I {
00004:   public int f();
00005:   public int g();
00006:   public void changeDirection();
00007: }
00008: 
00009: class C implements I {
00010:   private CState _state = new CStateMinus(this);
00011:   int _i;
00012:   int _j;
00013:   public int f() {
00014:     return _state.f();
00015:   }
00016:   public int g() {
00017:     return _state.g();
00018:   }
00019:   public void changeDirection() {
00020:     _state = _state.next();
00021:   }
00022: }
00023: 
00024: interface CState {
00025:   public int f();
00026:   public int g();
00027:   public CState next();
00028: }
00029: class CStateMinus implements CState {
00030:   C _x;
00031:   CStateMinus(C x) { _x = x; }
00032:   public int f() {
00033:     _x._i -= 32;
00034:     return _x._i;
00035:   }
00036:   public int g() {
00037:     _x._j -= 27;
00038:     return _x._j;
00039:   }
00040:   public CState next() {
00041:     return new CStatePlus(_x);
00042:   }
00043: }
00044: class CStatePlus implements CState {
00045:   C _x;
00046:   CStatePlus(C x) { _x = x; }
00047:   public int f() {
00048:     _x._i += 26;
00049:     return _x._i;
00050:   }
00051:   public int g() {
00052:     _x._j += 42;
00053:     return _x._j;
00054:   }
00055:   public CState next() {
00056:     return new CStateMinus(_x);
00057:   }
00058: }
00059:

State: Refactored to state using parameter [7/17]

file:I.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.two;
00002: 
00003: interface I {
00004:   public int f();
00005:   public int g();
00006:   public void changeDirection();
00007: }
00008: 
00009: class C implements I {
00010:   private CState[] _states = new CState[] { new CStateMinus(), new CStatePlus() };
00011:   private int _index;
00012:   int _i;
00013:   int _j;
00014:   public int f() {
00015:     return _states[_index].f(this);
00016:   }
00017:   public int g() {
00018:     return _states[_index].g(this);
00019:   }
00020:   public void changeDirection() {
00021:     _index = (_index+1) % 2;
00022:   }
00023: }
00024: 
00025: interface CState {
00026:   public int f(C x);
00027:   public int g(C x);
00028: }
00029: class CStateMinus implements CState {
00030:   public int f(C x) {
00031:     x._i -= 32;
00032:     return x._i;
00033:   }
00034:   public int g(C x) {
00035:     x._j -= 27;
00036:     return x._j;
00037:   }
00038: }
00039: class CStatePlus implements CState {
00040:   public int f(C x) {
00041:     x._i += 26;
00042:     return x._i;
00043:   }
00044:   public int g(C x) {
00045:     x._j += 42;
00046:     return x._j;
00047:   }
00048: }
00049:

State: Refactored to state using parameter and single instances [8/17]

file:I.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.three;
00002: 
00003: interface I {
00004:   public int f();
00005:   public int g();
00006:   public void changeDirection();
00007: }
00008: 
00009: class C implements I {
00010:   private CState _state = CState.MINUS;
00011:   private int _index;
00012:   int _i;
00013:   int _j;
00014:   public int f() {
00015:     return _state.f(this);
00016:   }
00017:   public int g() {
00018:     return _state.g(this);
00019:   }
00020:   public void changeDirection() {
00021:     _state = (_state==CState.MINUS) ? CState.PLUS : CState.MINUS;
00022:   }
00023: }
00024:

file:CState.java [source] [doc-public] [doc-private]
00001: package state.three;
00002: 
00003: interface CState {
00004:   public int f(C x);
00005:   public int g(C x);
00006: 
00007:   public static final CState MINUS = new CStateMinus();
00008:   public static final CState PLUS = new CStatePlus();
00009: }
00010: 
00011: class CStateMinus implements CState {
00012:   public int f(C x) {
00013:     x._i -= 32;
00014:     return x._i;
00015:   }
00016:   public int g(C x) {
00017:     x._j -= 27;
00018:     return x._j;
00019:   }
00020: }
00021: class CStatePlus implements CState {
00022:   public int f(C x) {
00023:     x._i += 26;
00024:     return x._i;
00025:   }
00026:   public int g(C x) {
00027:     x._j += 42;
00028:     return x._j;
00029:   }
00030: }
00031:

PSP: SEI [9/17]

PSP is the Personal Software Process developed by Humphries at CMU's Software Engineering Institute: SEI.

Interest is in process. What makes a project successful? What make a project fail?

PSP concentrates on the individual programmer. The Team Software Process (TSP) concentrates on Teams.

Goal is to distill knowledge and transmit it to others. SEI has done a very good job with this.

SE472 is a PSP course in the style advocated by SEI. This class is not.

The rest of these notes are copied from a talk given by Watts Humphries at DePaul in 2003.

PSP: Motivation [10/17]

Watts Humphrey: Our job is to transform poorly understood and rapidly changing needs into precise machine instructions.

Experimentation is necessary to determine what we are supposed to build, hence iterative development.

But software production is also a business, and businesses run on schedules and commitments.

So we need to measure what we do so that we know how to make plans and commitments.

PSP: Planning [11/17]

Quoting Watts Humphrey:

  • Never make a commitment without a plan.
  • The people who do the work make the plan.
  • If you can't plan accurately, plan often.
  • Plan what you know and plan at a level that fits the job.
  • If the plan does not fit the work, revise the plan.
  • Base plans on historical data.
    • comparable projects
    • similar plans
    • similar processes

PSP: Measurement [12/17]

Quoting Watts Humphrey:

  • To measure your work, you must define its measures.
  • To define the measures, you must know the job steps.
  • Tailor the process to fit the work.
    • For different kinds of work, use different processes.
    • Whe the process doesn't fit the job, change the process.
  • Use the process to measure, plan, and track the work.

PSP: What is needed? [13/17]

Quoting Watts Humphrey:

  • ... we need engineers who can
    • make accurate plans
    • consistently meet commitments
    • regularly produce quality products
  • The PSP provides engineers with the necessary skills.
  • The TSP builds teams that can
    • negotiate realistic commitments
    • accurately report progress
    • produce essentially defect-free products

PSP: Introducing Personal Disciplines [14/17]

Quoting Watts Humphrey:

  • Until they try it, most software professionals do not believe disciplined engineering will work for them.
    • They won't try it without evidence.
    • They can't get evidence without trying it.
  • The PSP course provides this experience.
    • Engineers write 10 programs.
    • They start with their current methods.
    • They advance in steps to the full PSP.
    • They gather data on every program.
  • They see from their own data that, with disciplined personal methods, they do better work.

PSP: The PSP [15/17]

We will only be doing a bit of measurement in this course.

  • Measure time.
  • Measure bugs.

I will also ask you to try to predict how much time you will spend. You can see how accurate your predictions are. With experience, you will get better at predicting.

Later stages of the PSP concentrate on:

  • Estimating code size
  • Design review
  • Code review
  • Cyclic development

Project [16/17]

The project will be a traffic simulation. Detailed instructions are here.
